did.unittitle: Mary Perry Smith Black Filmmakers Hall of Fame Archives Collection, Series 1. Publicity Materials

origination.label: Creator
origination.corpname: Black Filmmakers Hall of Fame, Inc.

did.abstract: This series contains publicity materials used to promote the Black Filmmakers Hall of Fame's events including souvenir programs, flyers, event announcements, invitations, posters, and tickets.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: This series is open for research.

bioghist.head: Administrative History
bioghist.p: The Black Filmmakers Hall of Fame, Inc. (BFHFI) was founded in Oakland, California in 1974. The BFHFI began as a collaboration among Roy Thomas from the Afro-American Studies Department at UC-Berkeley, Mary Perry Smith, who was the co-chairperson of the Cultural and Ethnic Affairs Guild and at the Oakland Museum, and Sonny Buxton of the San Francisco Bay Area station KGO-TV.

The BFHFI identified itself as an organization "dedicated to influencing Black images portrayed in film and television through education, the nurturing of current independent filmmakers and the preservation of contributions by Black artists" (BFHFI 20th Anniversary Celebration Program). Throughout its existence the BFHFI presented award ceremonies honoring contemporary and historic figures in black filmmaking. Notable programs established by the BFHFI include the Oscar Micheaux Awards Ceremony, the International Black Film, Video & Screenplay Competition, the Black Filmworks International Film Festival, and the Sidney Poitier Fellowship. Additionally, educational programs, various symposia, and lecture series on black film were conducted throughout the life of the organization.

The BFHFI initially operated in partnership with the Oakland Museum, later incorporating itself as an independent, non-profit organization in 1978. Attempts to establish a dedicated museum and permanent home for the BFHFI were not ultimately successful, although the BFHFI did begin acquisition of collections for this proposed museum.

The final Oscar Micheaux Awards ceremony was held in 1993, the 20th anniversary of the founding of the event. The BFHFI continued to present the Black Filmworks International Film Festival and Black Independent Film, Video & Screenplay Competition through 2003.

For a more detailed administrative history, a biography for Mary Perry Smith, and a listing of other series, please see collection overview (http://purl.dlib.indiana.edu/iudl/findingaids/bfca/VAD4347).

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection is arranged in the follow series with Series 1 containing twelve subseries:

list.item: -- Subseries 1.1. Oscar Micheaux Awards Ceremony (OMAC) and Celebrity Dinner and Dance Gala publicity materials, 1974-1996
-- Subseries 1.4. Miscellaneous BFHFI events publicity materials, 1972-2005
-- Subseries 1.8. BFHFI press kits and event packets, 1976-2002

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: This series contains publicity materials used to promote the Black Filmmakers Hall of Fame's events. The first subseries contains standard programs, souvenir programs, tickets, and invitations for annual Oscar Michaeux Awards Ceremony and Celebrity Dinner and Dance Gala, both of which were hosted from 1974-1993. There is also a ticket for a special gala hosted in 1996.
Signed programs are included with the Memorabilia and Artifacts series. Audiovisual records of the awards ceremony and gala are located in the BFHFI Event Recordings series.

relatedmaterial.head: Related materials
relatedmaterial.p: Additional administrative documents and audiovisual recordings related to the 1975 and 1991 awards ceremony and gala may be found in the Belva Davis and William Moore Black Filmmakers Hall of Fame Archives Collection (COL 6) also held by the Indiana University Black Film Center/Archive (http://purl.dlib.indiana.edu/iudl/findingaids/bfca/VAD4434).

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: The material in this series is part of a collection donated by Mary Perry Smith to the Indiana University Black Film Center Archives in January 2014.

userestrict.head: Usage Restrictions
userestrict.p: Materials may be used in-house at the BFC/A; duplication permitted only with permission of the Archivist.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [item], Mary Perry Smith Black Filmmakers Hall of Fame Archives Collection, Special Collection COL 5, Black Film Center/Archive, Indiana University, Bloomington.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Processed by Ronda L. Sewald and Ardea Smith.

scopecontent.head: Contents
scopecontent.p: Unsolicited offers, requests, and publicity from third parties. In some cases, material may be related to the BFHFI, but unable to easily determine relationship.
